page.title: 12THE ORIGIN OF PLACE NAMES
page.content: To many people Bishop's Tawton is just a straggling long village on the road from Barnstaple to Exeter. Its Saxon name denotes "the tun on the Taw", a stockaded farm which stretched from the old Exeter trackway down to the river. It nestles at the foot of Codden Hill which was the scene more than thirteen hundred years ago for the arrival of Christian missionaries who sailed up the Taw in their frail craft. One of them, a monk named Kea from Glastonbury gave his name to Landkey (the llan, or church, of Kea) which became a chapelry of the parish of Bishop's Tawton.
